title: History of Present Illness
content: Mr. Hutchinson is a follow-up patient presenting with persistent pain and swelling localized to the medial border of the proximal interphalangeal (PAP) joint. He reports that his symptoms have not resolved despite prior treatment with steroids, which were well-tolerated without side effects. He notes improvement in joint motion, though it remains suboptimal and not within normal range. The area of swelling and redness has become more localized to the medial aspect of the PAP joint. He is seeking clarification on the underlying cause of his ongoing symptoms. Imaging studies include a deferred X-ray and an ultrasound that revealed a hyperechoic lesion at the PAP joint, consistent with either calcification or crystals. An MRI is recommended for further evaluation to determine the etiology of the lesion and guide management.

title: Assessment and Plan
content: Assessment: Persistent pain and swelling localized to the medial border of the proximal interphalangeal (PAP) joint in Mr. Hutchinson, with incomplete resolution despite steroid therapy. Ultrasound demonstrates a hyperechoic lesion at the PAP joint, suggestive of either calcification or crystals. Differential diagnoses include gout, pseudogout, or localized calcific tendinitis. No systemic symptoms or constitutional signs are present. No prior comorbidities reported. The lesion is localized and not associated with systemic inflammation or joint deformity. The patient has improved motion but remains symptomatic.

Plan: Recommend MRI of the PAP joint for further evaluation to differentiate between calcification, crystal deposition, or soft tissue pathology. No immediate medication changes. Continue clinical monitoring. Patient education provided regarding the possible etiologies and next steps. No referrals or additional interventions at this time.
